content.description: Stand start on a large shelf to the right of the ten-foot pit in the cave. With a hard sequence, move from finger jam to another finger jam before thugging out a hard foot cut. Reset and continue climbing up while trending leftwards using a variety of jugs, pockets and meathooks. A somewhat tricky topout will get you on top of the boulder.
content.location: This boulder problem is found under the large roof and starts on a large shelf.

content.description: A relatively normal boulder problem in an unlikely location. As fun as it is hilarious. Start with your hands and right heel on a giant rail feature on the right side of the cave (where the opening is), and traverse left on the feature to its terminus, making a final move or two to an obvious jug above. Drop off, or step off. Laugh and do it again.
content.protection: a couple pads, a headlamp, a blubber pad would be nice for this area.
content.location: Locate Laws Of Gravity starting hold, and crawl down into the cave directly below it. This hole opens up into a room about half the size of the escape from reality cave containing a few drop off problems. The hole is human sized and is pretty easy to fit normal sized bouldering pads down through it.The whole thing is pretty laughable once you're down there. This problem is located at the entrance on an obvious rail feature.

content.protection: A minimum of 3 pads and a spotter, preferably two, one to move the pads. 5-8 pads would be ideal.
content.location:
This problem starts at the base of the crack system that flows through the middle of the large roof. 

 There is a chasm that drops around five feet in the back of the cave and this line climbs over the pit for the 3rd and 4th move. The void can be covered thoroughly with a large organic pad and the fall will be fairly safe.

content.description:
An amazing climb outshone by rock straight from the bargain basement!

  This boulder problem starts sitting inside the cave at the base of the crack on the right side of the pit. Right hand in a finger bucket and left hand on a smaller crimp. Pull onto the wall and move through the crack for a few moves before spinning around and moving diagonally out the roof. Hard rigid moves on stupendous roof features bring the climber to a crux lip encounter and a tough top out sequence! This climb follows the giant rail feature out of the roof while "Fighting the Laws of Gravity" starts the same but climbs following the finger crack out the middle of the roof.

 Although the rock quality isn't the best, this route offers some excellent horizontal roof climbing on large positive features, providing climbers with an excellent spot to hone their skills.
content.location: This problem starts in the far back of the middle section of the roof, and climb out and left, right over the irregular landscape. The problem has some dab potential but proper pad placement goes a long way.

content.description: Sit start underneath a bulbous feature on the roof with a good left hand sidepull pinch and a slightly worse pinch a few feet to the right. Campus on and find a foot before making a big move to a good hold. Swing the feet around then move up to another large flake. Once matched here, execute a big toss to the lip. From here, figure out how to match and then keep it together and don't pump out. Traverse left for full value or topout straight up. The traverse sequence incorporates the crux of "Caught in a Landslide" V6.
content.protection: Bring pads. 3-6. Landing is flat until the topout/ traverse.
content.location: This line is found on the right side of the large cave. There is a sort of prow feature that this problem starts on.

content.description: This is the boulder problem hidden away in a cave just above the main parking lot. Start sitting way back in the cave and crimp your way to the large underclings 3/4 of the way out. Match the last undercling and use a tiny crimp intermediate to throw big for the lip of the cave, then keep tight and work up to the obvious finishing 'spike.' Unfortunately several holds have broken over the past few years and some of the moves (particularly at the start) aren't as nice as they used to be. Still a great endurance boulder problem, though - something like 18 moves long and horizontal the whole way.
content.location: From the kiosk at the main parking lot, look up and left. You'll see a small looking cave. Now take the trail to your left that leads up towards the Holderness Corner. About 3/4's of the way up, you'll see a faint trail that trends down and right. This trail will get you to the cave & to the boulder problem.

content.description: Sit start the suspended lip of the boulder and climb up and right along the arete/ lip on large but sharp holds to a somewhat easy topout. This climb is the first section of "Caught in a Landslide", but instead of following the horizontal shelf across the roof, stay on the lip a few more moves then mantle onto the slab.
content.location: Sit-start on the outside of the large roof at the far right.

content.description: Sit start below the finishing jug of Party Pooper on two compression holds that are about two or three inches below the holds you actually want to start with and a big right foot. Pull on and use a low left heel to bump up to the better holds, and finish towards Going Deeper. Grab the huge jug and step back down to the pad.
content.protection: 2 pads, maybe a blubber pad would be nice, and you're gonna need a headlamp.
content.location: Locate Laws Of Gravity starting hold, and crawl down into the cave directly below it. This hole opens up into a room about half the size of the escape from reality cave containing a few drop off problems. The hole is human sized and is pretty easy to fit normal sized bouldering pads down through it. Dookie in the Ball Pit starts in the middle of the climbable part of the cave on two opposing holds just below a decent left hand crimp and a decent right hand crimp.

content.protection: 3-8 pads and 2 spotters. The landing is relatively flat until the end sequence post-crux, where it becomes blocky and hazardous.
content.location: This problem starts sitting on the right side of the roof, but not under the roof. There is a rock you can sit-start on comfortably.

content.description: A fun roof problem on large reinforced holds. Sit start with a large jug shelf above the pit. Pull on and execute powerful moves along the shelf system. Avoid a dab near the end of the roof and commit to a good topout.
content.location: This problem starts on large holds in the middle of the cave and climbs out left.

content.description: This is a horizontal roof hidden just below the parking lot wall. On the right side of the roof is Todd Bradlee's roof test-piece Escape From Reality (V9). There are also two other lines under here that look to be about the difficulty. These other two unknown lines are both to the left of Escape From Reality.
